entry.title: My First Triathlon: Graduation Is Not the End, But a New Beginning
entry.content:
üèÖ My First Triathlon: Graduation Is Not the End, But a New Beginning

by Ezra Wu | Jul 4, 2025

That was a 1 hour and 40 minutes challenge.

I participated in a triathlon for the first time in my life‚Äîrunning and rafting‚Äîon a hilly course. Halfway through, my body refused to cooperate, leaving only my willpower to push me forward.

Along the way, there were thoughtful aid stations with slices of watermelon. It was so hot and I was so thirsty that I accidentally ate too much, and ended up ‚Äúvomiting watermelon juice‚Äù while running‚Äîboth embarrassing and funny. Every step felt like a battle with myself, and in my mind, I even imagined my loved one running ahead, just to keep me going.

I was exhausted‚Äîso tired‚Äîbut I wanted to prove that I could push through.

üèÜ The Ceremony of My ‚ÄúFirst Time‚Äù Was Not in a Hall, But in the Wilderness

Crossing the finish line, I felt an incredible rush.

Sweat, vomiting, watermelon, imagination, persistence, acceleration‚Äîall mixed together in a way words can‚Äôt describe. All I knew was: I made it. I finished.

The rafting afterward was even more exhilarating. The waves of Xiuguluan River, the sunshine, and the staff‚Äôs playful splashes instantly pulled me out of my fatigue. Laughter echoed everywhere, and I met some new friends who were just as passionate, brave, and willing to challenge themselves.

At that moment, a thought came to me:

‚ÄúThis is my university graduation ceremony.‚Äù

Not sitting in an auditorium, listening to someone give a speech‚Äîbut pushing my limits, facing the unknown, and finishing with a smile.

üå± Growing Up Is Not Scary; What‚Äôs Scary Is Not Writing Your Own Story

After finishing the duathlon, I no longer feared growing up.

Because I realized that true ‚Äúgrowing up‚Äù is not measured by age, but by whether we can bravely face challenges, get through low points, and then, on a sunny afternoon, smile at ourselves.

There are many more races and countless unpredictable adventures ahead, but I am ready to continue writing this journey‚Äîone page at a time.

Let every challenge become the most passionate chapter in my story.

entry.title: The Coolest Thing I've Ever Done
entry.content:
The Coolest Thing I‚Äôve Ever Done: Building an AI Learning Tool for Visually Impaired Children

By Ezra Wu | April 5, 2025

The Beginning: A Spark of an Idea

In October 2024, I saw the announcement for the Microsoft Imagine Cup. A thought flashed through my mind: What if we could really use technology to change the world?

The first prize was a whopping $100,000, but more than the money, what drew me in was the possibility of making a real impact.

How It Started: One Phone Call

My first teammate was a high school student I met during a competition in China. We weren‚Äôt close at first, but we shared a common interest: creating something meaningful for society.

We decided to focus on the visually impaired. Our initial idea was to develop a smart cane. But we didn‚Äôt want to guess the users‚Äô needs‚Äîwe wanted to understand them deeply.

We started by calling 50 blind massage centers in Yunlin and Changhua. These interviews gave us a glimpse into the lives of visually impaired people, but we wanted to go further.

With the help of a school professor, we were able to visit Huiming Blind School. There, teachers and students revealed the biggest pain point in Taiwan‚Äôs special education: learning resources are expensive and limited.

A Global Team

Interestingly, our project evolved into a truly international collaboration.

Our team spread across South Africa, Australia, India, Vietnam, and China, meeting weekly on Discord. Time zones, languages, cultures‚Äîevery aspect was a challenge, but it made the journey unique.

I vividly remember our third full-team meeting. I was sipping Jin Xuan tea, thinking: Wow, I‚Äôm actually discussing how to help blind children with friends from all over the world.

The pressure was intense, but the excitement and sense of mission kept me going.

What We Built

We decided to develop an AI learning platform specifically for low-vision children. Think of it as a Notebook LM for the visually impaired, focused on auditory learning and personalized instruction.

The AI assistant can read content aloud, answer questions, generate quizzes, and even identify learning gaps to provide tailored suggestions.

We also built a content management system for teachers to create their own lesson databases and track each student‚Äôs progress, helping them move forward step by step.

Struggles and Challenges

Reality was far more complicated than our ideal.

The Microsoft resources we received ran out in the first month, and we had to cover all cloud costs ourselves. Cross-time-zone meetings were sometimes chill, sometimes high-pressure, often in the middle of the night, which took a toll on our bodies and minds.

By early 2025, I was diagnosed with depression. I hit rock bottom, constantly asking myself: Should I keep going?

But when I thought of the children we interviewed and the laughter, debates, and breakthroughs from our brainstorming sessions, I knew I couldn‚Äôt give up.

Together, we built the MVP. That moment, I genuinely felt: We are unstoppable.

Watch Our AI Project in Action

Check out our project demo video on YouTube:

Afterword: Connection and Continuation

Although we didn‚Äôt advance in the Imagine Cup, our project is now submitted to the 2025 BCM Social Entrepreneurship Competition. We are preparing a second visit to Huiming Blind School to continue improving the platform.

That friend from China still keeps in touch, sharing new tech ideas. Andy from Australia found a new job, yet we still reminisce about the nights we worked together until the early morning.

This experience taught me that projects aren‚Äôt about competitions‚Äîthey‚Äôre about the people you want to help.

If you ask me the coolest thing I‚Äôve ever done, I would answer without hesitation:

It‚Äôs building a tool with friends from around the world, for children who cannot see, that helps them see their future.

entry.title: Why I Deleted All My Social Media
entry.content:
Why I Deleted All My Social Media | Choosing to Give My Attention Back to Myself

Social media drained my focus, my thoughts, and my sense of real connection.
It wasn‚Äôt until I let it go that I finally found myself again.

A few months ago, I deleted all of my social media accounts.
No farewell post, no dramatic announcement‚Äîjust silence. I only kept Gmail as my way of staying in touch.

It wasn‚Äôt an impulsive decision. It was the result of months of inner struggle, a choice made for healing and for reclaiming my focus.

I Cared Too Much About People Who Didn‚Äôt Care About Me

At one point, I was spending nearly eight hours a day on Instagram.
I checked who posted a story, who replied to my messages, who ignored me, whose life looked better than mine.

It wasn‚Äôt their fault‚Äîit was mine.
I cared too much about people who never cared back.

This over-caring left me mentally exhausted.
I thought I was ‚Äúmaintaining connections,‚Äù but in reality, I was letting algorithms hijack my attention in exchange for emptiness.

I Asked Myself: Is This Information Changing Me?

One day, I sat down and asked myself:

If the information I consume daily shapes my thoughts,
then what are these endless scrolls doing to me?

The questions piled up:

  • Am I letting my brain be filled with fragments of noise?
  • Am I replacing real thinking with shallow topics?
  • Am I mistaking fake, polished lives for ‚Äúnormal‚Äù?
  • Has my way of speaking become restless and hollow because of this?
  • Has my self-image been twisted by the content I consume?

The answers were terrifying. Almost all of them were yes.

Choosing to Keep Only What Feeds Me

I made a deal with myself: if I‚Äôm going to spend one hour each day consuming content, then I must consciously choose what it is.

So I divided information into two categories:

Worthwhile, nourishing content:

  • Thoughtful podcasts (knowledge, inspiration)
  • Insightful YouTube channels (documentaries, culture, education)
  • Articles and blogs that share honest perspectives
  • Beautifully crafted games (where design, sound, and story matter)

Low-quality distractions to avoid:

  • AI-generated endless short videos
  • ‚ÄúCotton candy‚Äù content that gives dopamine but no depth
  • Shallow Instagram posts of curated lifestyles
  • Empty viral gimmicks with no creativity

This simple filter redefined what counts as leisure and what is simply wasted time.

I Found Back My Words‚Äîand Myself

After deleting social media, I felt lighter.
No more notifications to check every minute. No more envy or insecurity from watching others.

Instead, I now enjoy deep conversations with two or three people who truly matter. I find joy in books, blogs, writing, learning, and exercising.

There was a time when I stopped reading, and my vocabulary shrank until I felt almost speechless.
But now, I‚Äôve reclaimed my language, my focus‚Äîmost importantly, myself.

A Reminder: Your Attention Is Your Most Precious Resource

I‚Äôm not saying you should delete all your accounts today.
But I do invite you to ask yourself this:

‚ÄúDoes what I scroll through every day actually make me better?‚Äù

If the answer is no, then maybe it‚Äôs time to give your attention‚Äîand your life‚Äîback to yourself.

Q&A: Common Questions About Quitting Social Media

Q1: What if I miss something important?
Don‚Äôt worry. Truly important things will reach you.
If the world were collapsing tomorrow, your friends, family, or coworkers wouldn‚Äôt rely on Instagram to tell you.

Q2: Will my friendships disappear without IG or Facebook?
No. Real friendships don‚Äôt vanish with a deleted account.
Those who care about you will still find you. The ones who don‚Äôt? They weren‚Äôt truly close to begin with.

Q3: How do I stay connected without social media?
By reaching out intentionally. I now use Gmail, LINE, or SMS for people who matter. I schedule calls, write emails, or meet in person. These connections feel more real than likes and stories ever did.

Q4: Won‚Äôt I feel lonely?
You‚Äôll feel quiet, not lonely.
At first, it‚Äôs strange because we‚Äôre used to filling every silence with noise. But soon you realize‚Äîloneliness isn‚Äôt the lack of information, it‚Äôs the inability to be with yourself. Once you start reading, writing, exercising, or creating, you‚Äôll find freedom.

Q5: Will I miss out on trends or news?
Not really. In fact, I‚Äôm more focused now. I choose what I consume: newsletters, podcasts, and selected sites. Instead of being force-fed by algorithms, I practice information subtraction. That gives me clarity and control.

üëâ Your attention is your life. Don‚Äôt waste it on things that don‚Äôt deserve it.

entry.title: The Birth of Our Metaverse English Club
entry.content:
In 2024, I co-founded a club that quickly became one of my favorite projects: the Metaverse English Research Club. What makes this club special is its commitment to creating a fun, interactive, and immersive learning environment. We wanted to break the fear often associated with learning English, replacing it with curiosity and joy.

Our approach is playful and innovative. Through gamified teaching, virtual reality (VR) experiences, and even board games, members engage with English in ways that feel natural, tangible, and exciting. Every session is designed so that learning feels less like a task and more like an adventure.

Working alongside Joseph, we‚Äôve turned the club into more than just a language-learning space. It‚Äôs a mini technological lab, a place where creativity meets education, and a community built with care and passion. Members don‚Äôt just improve their English‚Äîthey experience it, practice it, and enjoy it in a supportive, vibrant environment.

No matter your current level of English, the club offers a chance to discover the joy of learning, and to grow continuously in a relaxed and inspiring atmosphere. It‚Äôs a small experiment in blending technology, education, and human connection‚Äîbut one that has left a lasting mark on everyone involved.
